solution_03_central_limit_theorem/02_normal/01_compare_zs_v3

video

The formula to determine the \(z\)-score of a measurement is the ratio with numerator the difference between measurement and population mean and denominator the population standard deviation.

\[z = \frac{x-\mu}{\sigma} \]

The highest \(z\)-score (furthest right on number line) corresponds to the most unusually large measurement.

The smallest \(z\)-score (furthest left on number line) corresponds to the most unusually small measurement.

The smallest absolute \(z\)-score corresponds to the most usually sized measurement.

The largest absolute \(z\)-score corresponds to the most unusually sized measurement.


  1. We use the formula for calculating the plum specimen’s \(z\) score. \[z = \frac{81.54-93}{6} = -1.91 \]
  2. Use the \(z\) table to find the cumulative probability \[P(Z<-1.91) = 0.0281 \]
  3. We use the formula for calculating the orange specimen’s \(z\) score. \[z = \frac{156.2-144}{8} = 1.52 \]
  4. Use the \(z\) table to find the cumulative probability \[P(Z<1.52) = 0.9357 \]
  5. We use the formula for calculating the grapefruit specimen’s \(z\) score. \[z = \frac{204.1-192}{13} = 0.93 \]
  6. Use the \(z\) table to find the cumulative probability \[P(Z<0.93) = 0.8238 \]
  7. We use the formula for calculating the lemon specimen’s \(z\) score. \[z = \frac{109.4-117}{10} = -0.76 \]
  8. Use the \(z\) table to find the cumulative probability \[P(Z<-0.76) = 0.2236 \]
  9. We determine the maximum \(z\) score is \(1.52\), which belongs to the orange. / . / . / .
  10. We determine the minimum \(z\) score is \(-1.91\), which belongs to the plum. / . / . / .
  11. We determine the minimum absolute \(z\) score is \(0.76\), which belongs to the lemon. / . / . / .
  12. We determine the maximum absolute \(z\) score is \(1.91\), which belongs to the plum. / . / . / .
